string-array.name: hints
string-array.item: Notice your breath - wherever you can sense it most easily.
You don\'t need to locate your breath in a specific location. Just be aware of it - however it appears.
Notice the sensations of the breath in the belly.
Notice the sensations of the breath in the chest.
Notice the sensations of the breath at the nostrils.
Notice the breath as a whole.
Notice how the whole body is breathing.
Notice how, in a way, the breath is everywhere.
Notice your breath as a continuous flow.
When noticing your breath, zoom further in to note the sensations that make up those sensations.
Notice if there are parts of your breath you are pulling away from.
Notice if there are parts of your breath you are pushing away.
Notice if there are parts of your breath you are pulled towards.
Notice if there are parts of your breath you are pushing towards.
Notice if you are rather approaching your breath, moving away from it, or neither.
Note what can be sensed between out-breath and in-breath.
Note what can be sensed between in-breath and out-breath.
You may try to lean a tiny bit forward.
You may try to lean a tiny bit backwards.
You may try to open your jaw a tiny bit further.
You may try to close your jaw a tiny bit more.
What if you don\'t care about the sensations of your breath at all?
This time, don\'t focus at all.
Notice that your body is constantly moving (you\'re not a Stone Buddha).
Notice how there are movements everywhere in the body.
Notice how sensations arise in awareness without you doing anything.
What if you watched each breath as if it was something precious?
What if you watched each breath as if it was the most unremarkable thing?
There may be thoughts that catch you quicker than you even notice.
There may be thoughts that seem more intriguing than the breath.
What if the breath belonged to someone you care for?
Observe the breath through the eyes of someone who cares for you.
What is between the thoughts?
What is there beyond your current sensory experience?
Try to zoom in and zoom out simultaneously.
In a way, the breath is watching you.
